body:
Disagree with deprecation - I would still suggest to try to support it, in addition.

I also think we need to take care of the "multiple input types" issue cleanly once and for all, including light-weight architecture for type conversions and type checks. See discussion at the end of #420.

The nested pd.DataFrame causes a lot of headaches all over the place (conversions, input checks, loading, checking for equality, obtaining shapes, etc, etc), besides that most operations on it are very slow. I'd really prefer to deprecate it in the long run.

> I'd really prefer to deprecate it in the long run.

So do I, but I don't see a viable alternative yet for samples of unequally sampled, unequal length time series with named variables.

As long as deprecating it would mean deprecating an entire scitype central to the sktime vision, I'll be against it.

I have data frame whose features are monthly electricity consumption of thousand different users and target variable is customer is either healthy or involved in theft...My data format is typical pandas data frame as you see titanic data set having number of features and in the end survival as target...
since electricity consumption data is time series, how to convert pandas data frame to suitable sktime format
Can you help me how to convert pandas data frame having X as features and y as target into sktime....
Hi @SaddamHussain84 that's probably best discussed in a separate issue, please create a new one and add some simple example data, that would be most helpful to answer your question!

> > I'd really prefer to deprecate it in the long run.
> 
> So do I, but I don't see a viable alternative yet for samples of unequally sampled, unequal length time series with named variables.
> 
> As long as deprecating it would mean deprecating an entire scitype central to the sktime vision, I'll be against it.

About that. I am considering going from a custom data pipeline implementation based on pandas to using sktime for just this kind of data:

- Multi-channel
- Multi-object (panel data)
- Time heterogeneous (unequal spacing between samples within and across channels)
- Ragged (panels of different duration, both in time and sample count)
- Indexed by datetime rather than int

Until now I haven't dared make the move, because I haven't seen examples of this kind of data in use with sktime. If it was possible, sktime seems to be just the platform I need.

Is this well supported in sktime today? Have you gotten closer to figuring out if this will remain a goal for the project?

I really miss a serious toolbox for generalized time series data that does cover more than the "ordinal sequence" subset of this space.

Hi @harahu, unfortunately we haven't made much progress in that direction. The fundamental challenge is the data container. awkward-array seems to be the most promising solution. The other challenge is extending algorithms to handle that kind of data. 

sktime does offer some support for multivariate panel data (multi-channel and multi-object), but not time-heterogenous data. 

What other tools have you worked with so far to handle that kind of data?

The nested `pd.DataFrame` structure was meant to address exactly that use case!
I believe it's quite common in "serious" applications, equal length, equal time points etc is often a bit artificial...

Indeed the problem is the data container representation, nested `pd.DataFrame` is a bit of a hack.
Though, getting a clean container plus interface would hinge on volunteer contributions - which may be unlikely in the close future, because most people like to work on exciting methodology rather than on the data back-end...
... would you be interested to help, @harahu?

@mloning:
> What other tools have you worked with so far to handle that kind of data?

Mostly custom developed tooling, based on pandas, where calculations are done by first "translating" the general data formats mentioned above to more limited formats expected by mainstream time series tooling. Not highly efficient. In other words, I have never actually experienced a tool set that makes it easy to work with this kind of data. A semi-exception might be [traces](https://github.com/datascopeanalytics/traces), by @stringertheory et al. They have a great API design that makes working with ragged, time heterogeneous data easy, but I don't think the internals make it scalable to truly big datasets and massive computation. 

@fkiraly:
> I believe it's quite common in "serious" applications, equal length, equal time points etc is often a bit artificial...

That is my experience as well. My domain is sensor data from process industry. It is quite common for me to be looking at datasets that span multiple years, consisting of a mix of high and low frequency channels. It is then common to represent it in a "sparse" way, where you only get a reading when there is an actual change in the signal, to avoid low frequency channels eating up valuable memory. The assumption is that you can usually just forward fill the last seen value to any time point to get a continuously valid signal. Going from this format to supported formats in most time series libraries is painful.

> Indeed the problem is the data container representation, nested `pd.DataFrame` is a bit of a hack.
> Though, getting a clean container plus interface would hinge on volunteer contributions - which may be unlikely in the close future, because most people like to work on exciting methodology rather than on the data back-end...
> ... would you be interested to help, @harahu?

I would love to, but if I am being honest with myself I am merely a heavy user of the Pandas API, I don't know a lot about what goes on under the hood. I don't know much about the alternatives you are evaluating either, like awkward arrays. I might be able to help out if there is anything concrete you need doing.

Perhaps the above-mentioned @stringertheory has thoughts on this? Sorry for @-ing you, but your experience seems like a really good fit here.

Hey @harahu, no worries about @-ing, this is interesting, and I'm happy to learn about Awkward Arrays. They seem useful!

I agree with all the points in this thread:

- time-heterogeneous data is common in practice, especially with sensors and other event-driven systems
- [traces](https://github.com/datascopeanalytics/traces) is intended for time-heterogeneous data, but prioritizes ease of use on messy small-to-medium datasets over scalability (e.g. I find that I start getting impatient with it around ~10 million points or so on a laptop)
- also +1 to what @mloning mentions around needing to extend time series algorithms. Even the underlying [theory/methodology for time-heterogeneous data is lacking](http://www.eckner.com/papers/Algorithms%20for%20Unevenly%20Spaced%20Time%20Series.pdf) and/or very specialized according to specific use cases. For "basic" algorithms like a Fast Fourier Transform, time-heterogeneous data requires fundamental changes in the algorithms or a translation to even spacing, and there [are lots of ways to do it](https://scicomp.stackexchange.com/questions/593/how-do-i-take-the-fft-of-unevenly-spaced-data).

As you mention, whenever I need to use a more powerful toolset for time series analysis, I also end up making a (careful) translation to evenly-spaced data.

If anyone digs into this, it might be worth investigating the most efficient way of interpolating between time points in time-heterogenous data (maybe using or inspired by [scipy interpolation](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.interpolate.interp1d.html#scipy.interpolate.interp1d)?). That's ultimately what is needed in order to apply the toolset that's intended for evenly-spaced data. Traces uses [sortedcontainers](https://github.com/grantjenks/python-sortedcontainers) for that (sortedcontainers is a great library!), but maybe there are ways of interpolating between points in Awkward Arrays that would be more scalable.
